The inverting amplifier is a very flexible concept.
We now know that for two resistors, the gain of this configuration approaches \( \frac{v_O}{v_I} = - \frac{R_F}{R_S} \) as the op amp approaches the ideal.
We have also learned that this idea can be generalized to elements that store energy. For example, if we use a capacitor in the feedback path (\(U_F\) is a capacitor of capacitance \(C\) and \(U_S\) is a resistor of resistance \(R\)), then
\( v_O = -\frac{1}{R C}\int_{-\infty}^t v_I(t) dt \)
Suppose that we make \(U_S\) an inductor with inductance \(L\) and \(U_F\) a resistor with resistance \(R\). Using the same reasoning we will also get an integrator of the form:
\( v_O = A\int_{-\infty}^t v_I(t) dt \)
